choices: systolic arterial blood pressure is at least 60 mm Hg.
body’s demand for oxygen is markedly increased.
body’s temperature is considerably less than 98.6°F (37.0°C).
heart rate is maintained at more than 100 beats/min.
front.question: An organ or tissue might better resist damage from hypoperfusion if the:

cards.back: body’s temperature is considerably less than 98.6°F (37.0°C).

choices: An intact system of blood vessels
The filtering of blood cells in the spleen
front.question: Which of the following body systems or components is the least critical for supplying and maintaining adequate blood flow to the body?
front.source: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Cardiovascular System

cards.back: The filtering of blood cells in the spleen

front.question: Which of the following organs can tolerate inadequate perfusion for two to three hours?
The severity of bleeding should be based on all of the following findings, except:

choices: blood typically oozes from a vein.
veins are under a lower pressure.
front.question: External bleeding from a vein is relatively easy to control because:

cards.back: veins are under a lower pressure.

front.question: Internal bleeding into a fractured extremity is most often controlled by:
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care for External Bleeding

front.question: Capillaries link the arterioles and the:
front.source: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Cardiovascular System

choices: at least 10% of the patient’s blood volume is lost.
low fluid volume leads to inadequate perfusion.
the clotting ability of the blood is enhanced.
the patient’s systolic BP is less than 100 mm Hg.
front.question: Hypovolemic shock occurs when:

cards.back: low fluid volume leads to inadequate perfusion.

choices: should be assumed to be caused by a fractured septum.
is a sign of a skull fracture and should not be stopped.
is usually due to hypertension caused by the head injury.
should be controlled by packing the nostril with gauze.
front.question: Bleeding from the nose following head trauma:
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care for External Bleeding

cards.back: is a sign of a skull fracture and should not be stopped.

front.question: Hypoperfusion is another name for:
front.source: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Cardiovascular System

choices: ability of the systemic arteries to constrict as needed to maintain an adequate blood pressure.
effective transfer of oxygen from the venules across the systemic capillary membrane walls.
effective removal of carbon dioxide and other metabolic waste products from the body’s cells.
circulation of blood within an organ in adequate amounts to meet the body’s metabolic needs.
front.question: Perfusion is most accurately defined as the:

cards.back: circulation of blood within an organ in adequate amounts to meet the body’s metabolic needs.

front.question: A fractured femur can result in the loss of ______ or more of blood into the soft tissues of the thigh.

choices: how rapidly he or she bleeds.
how fast his or her heart beats.
the part of the body injured.
his or her baseline blood pressure.
front.question: The ability of a person’s cardiovascular system to compensate for blood loss is most related to:

cards.back: how rapidly he or she bleeds.
